page.title: 16ST NICHOLAS, ODDINGTON
page.content: The Church of St Nicholas, Oddington, stands near the original village site abandoned during the Black Death. A plague pit is thought to exist near the deep, protective ditch partly surrounding the church yard in which there are seven yew trees and a carved tomb of a woman who died in childbirth. On the wall is a stick sundial. Painted on the North wall is a 14th century doom painting showing the Last Judgement with angels and devils. There is a richly carved Jacobean pulpit where a vixen is reputed to have raised her cubs. The Rails and Altar Table are Cromwellian. In the doorway are grooves on benches where arrows were sharpened. The oldest parts of the church are the aisle, the chapel and the Norman arch. As there is no heating or lighting, the church is only used in summer.
